```{python}
# Sample line chart: sine and cosine
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

x = np.linspace(0, 2 * np.pi, 200)
y1 = np.sin(x)
y2 = np.cos(x)

plt.style.use('seaborn-v0_8')
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(8, 4))
ax.plot(x, y1, label='sin(x)', color='#1f77b4')
ax.plot(x, y2, label='cos(x)', color='#ff7f0e')
ax.set_title('Sample Line Chart — Sine and Cosine')
ax.set_xlabel('x')
ax.set_ylabel('value')
ax.legend()
ax.grid(alpha=0.3)

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
```

Figure: A sample line chart produced with matplotlib (sine and cosine).

```{python}
# Sample bar chart: categorical values
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

categories = ['A', 'B', 'C', 'D', 'E']
values = [23, 45, 12, 37, 29]

plt.style.use('seaborn-v0_8')
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(7, 4))
bars = ax.bar(categories, values, color=['#2ca02c', '#1f77b4', '#ff7f0e', '#d62728', '#9467bd'], edgecolor='black')
ax.set_title('Sample Bar Chart — Categorical Values')
ax.set_xlabel('Category')
ax.set_ylabel('Value')
ax.grid(axis='y', alpha=0.3)

# Add value labels on top of bars
for bar in bars:
    height = bar.get_height()
    ax.annotate(f'{height}',
                xy=(bar.get_x() + bar.get_width() / 2, height),
                xytext=(0, 4),
                textcoords='offset points',
                ha='center', va='bottom', fontsize=9)

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
```

Figure: A sample bar chart produced with matplotlib (categorical values).
